It has been argued by members of the Labour party that we should fix a home consumption price for wool. No doubt that has emanated from their socialist friends in the United Kingdom, because I have just received information which may be news and perhaps a warning to some people. The report is that in the United Kingdom the wool clip has been acquired by the Government until 1954 at an average price of 2s. per lb. sterling plus 3 3/4 d. per lb. for expenses, a total in Australian currency of 2s. lid. per lb. Perhaps honorable members opposite had that scheme in view when they advocated certain thing's for the wool industry in the plausible, if not hypocritical way that they have done in the course of this debate. It might be suggested that the Labour party would do with the wool industry what it previously did with regard to sheepskins. In 1930 it endeavoured to impose an excise duty on sheepskins. In the last day of the sitting in 1930 the Labour Government rushed through the House legislation to this effect -

quote.para: On and after the eleventh day of December one thousand nine hundred and thirty at 9 o'clock in the forenoon reckoned according to standard time in the territory for the seat of Government, duties of customs are imposed according to the following tariff: -
Sheepskins with wool 4d. a lb.

speech.para: The House divided on that motion and amongst those who voted for the proposed tariff were the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Chifley), the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway), and the honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Lazzarini). The protests against that action were so widespread and determined that on the second day after the Parliament resumed sitting in March, 1931, the Government withdrew the legislation without giving any reason for its action. Perhaps honorable members opposite had that in mind as a remedy for the inflationary position of the wool industry. If they did that with sheepskins in 1930 what would they do with wool, which is now selling at £150 a bale? Let the wool industry realize the possibility that had the Labour party been in power there would have been no prepayment of tax but a straight-out export duty. We are asked to believe that the

Opposition does not endorse sectional taxation and we are told that this tax is a sectional tax and that the wool industry has been singled out for attack. The defence requirements of every democratic nation have singled out the wool industry because wool is a commodity of inestimable defence value, and the fact that the world is expending large sums of money on defence preparations has meant that the wool industry has benefited by receiving high prices for its commodity. As a result of the preparations that are being made throughout the world, Australia is involved in an increase of its defence expenditure to the amount of £79,000,000.

The honorable member for Fremantle shed crocodile tears about this so-called tax. He said that it was most iniquitous and of a type that had not been heard of since federation. He claimed that the Government had singled out this industry and had taxed it on its gross income. Is the honorable member's memory so short that he does not remember, or it convenient for him to forget, that in his own State of Western Australia the gold mining industry was singled out to bear the imposition of a gold tax that took all proceeds from the sale of gold above a 50 per cent, increase over the pre-war price of gold? That act was suspended only in December, 1947, after the Chifley Government had continued it up to that time. Therefore the Opposition's criticism that the proposed wool sales deduction is a forced loan is arrant humbug. Neither is it a tax, much less an iniquitous, discriminatory and confiscatory tax. Honorable members opposite have repeatedly said that it is a compulsory loan. What is provisional tax, in fact? Ever since it inception provisional tax has been assessed on the income of the preceding year. It has been collected in the current year as a forward payment of the tax that will be payable in respect of income of the current year. Members of the Opposition have also said that under this proposal the Government, in effect, is mortgaging its budget. At least the Leader of the Opposition should know that section 81 of the Constitution requires that all revenues or moneys raised or received by the Government shall constitute one Consolidated Revenue Fund. For that reason the Chifley Government, for a period of five years, paid the whole of its provisional tax collections into that fund. This Government simply proposes to continue that practice, as it is obliged to do under the Constitution. Therefore, it is humbug for the Opposition to say that this proposal is a departure from past practice or that it is unsound from an accountancy standpoint. No one would compare the Consolidated Revenue Fund, in respect of which the Constitution lays it down that certain requirements shall be observed by the Government, with the profit and loss account of an ordinary business or the income and expenditure account of a club or a. similar organization. The Consolidated Revenue Account is a summarized statement of the cash book of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: - The statement that the right honorable gentleman has made about the assessment and payment of provisional tax is not correct.

- Obviously, provisional tax is a prepayment of tax which is assessed on the basis of the preceding year's income in respect of the income of the current year and is payable in the current year. It is humbug for members of the Opposition to say that under this proposal the Government intends to do something different from what the Government that they supported did. The fact is that that Government observed the requirements of the Constitution in this respect, and the present Government must do likewise.
- Does not this proposal involve the payment of an additional provisional tax?
- I shall explain that point later. Honorable members opposite have said that under this proposal the Government will raise a compulsory loan from the wool-growers.
- So it will.

- Under the pay as you earn system, all employees have deductions made from their wages as prepayment of their tax liabilities. In 1944-45 collections of income tax under that method amounted to £81,805,000 and during the following year £4,522,000 of that amount was refunded to taxpayers who had overpaid their tax.
- A small proportion.

- Well, I ask the honorable member for Dalley (Mr. Rosevear) to listen to the figures in respect of the following years. In 1945-46, out of a total collection of £81,467,000 under the pay-as-you-earn system, £8,689,000 was refunded to taxpayers. During the next year, out of a total collection of £85,307,000, refunds of tax totalled £12,694,000; and in 1948-49, out of a total collection of £86,562,000, the total refunded to taxpayers was £13,544,000, or 15* per cent, of the total amount collected in that year. I am not criticizing the pay-as-you-earn system. Experience has shown that it is the most practical system that can be evolved to meet the special circumstances that exist to-day. However, I strongly object to the hypocrisy of members of the Opposition when they say that, by making deductions from the incomes of wool-growers from the sale of wool as a prepayment of their future tax liability the Government is doing something different from what the Chifley Government did. On the basis of their argument, taxes paid by the ordinary taxpayer under the pay as you earn system can with equal justification be described as compulsory loans. However, the worker who pays tax under that system cannot obtain immediate redress in the event of hardship or a change of circumstances after tax has been deducted from his weekly wages. He must wait to obtain such redress until after he has lodged his return and his tax has been duly assessed. In 1949-50, of a total number of 2,500,000 taxpayers who paid tax under the pay as you earn system, approximately 2,100,000 received a refund. To use the Opposition's own argument, that means that the Chifley Government in that year raised a forced loan of approximately £13,500,000 from 2,100,000 taxpayers. I repeat that the proposed wool sales deduction is not a forced loan, hut a prepayment of the grower's future tax liability. What the Government is doing in this respect is precisely what it is required to do and what the previous Government was required to do under section 81 of the Constitution. The honorable member for Dalley asked me a question with respect to provisional tax.
- Is not the provisional tax for which a part of this deduction is to be used an additional provisional tax?
- Of course, it is.
- So, the wool-growers will be obliged to pay the tax twice.

- I have explained that provisional tax ordinarily payable this year would be based on the income of the grower for the preceding year. So long as the income remains steady, the provisional tax approximates the tax ultimately assessed. But what is the position of the wool-growers to-day? The provisional tax to be collected ordinarily this year is based on an aggregate income of £225,000,000 earned in 1949-50. But the taxable income of wool-growers for this year will undoubtedly bie in the aggregate much greater than that sum. It will be approximately £375,000,000, or £150,000,000 more. Therefore, the provisional tax in respect of wool-growers should be assessed this year on an income £150,000,000 in excess of their aggregate actual income last year. If the provisional tax had been assessed on that basis, £65,000,000 to £70,000,000 of the proposed £103,000,000 would have been paid.

speech.para: Members of the Opposition have claimed that in cases of hardship wool-growers will suffer terrible injury under this proposal. Those honorable members have criticized the proposal to make a flat-rate deduction of 20 per cent. In the absence of adequate machinery that would enable deductions to be made at varying rates and having regard to the fact that, in order that inflation may be curbed, a proportion of the income from wool sales must be deducted at the source, as well as the urgency of defence commitments, the Government had no alternative but to make the deduction at a flat rate. Whereas, on the average, wool-growers received £80 a bale for their wool last year, which was a record price, this year they are receiving on the average £150 a bale, or- a fortuitous increase of £70 a bale. That windfall has been contributed to by the expenditure that the democracies are being obliged to incur in respect of their defence requirements. Out of that additional £70 a bale, the Government will withhold under this proposal £30 not as a tax or as a forced loan, but as a prepayment of the grower's future tax liability. The grower will still retain £40 of that £70 and will thus receive on the average this year £120 a bale for his wool compared with the £80 a bale that he received last year. In view of those facts how can it be said that the small grower will be adversely affected under this proposal? I am old enough to realize that some cases of hardship are bound to arise just as they arise inevitably under any taxation proposal. It is for that reason that the income tax law makes provision in respect of cases of hardship and that appeal boards have been set up throughout the country in order to provide relief where the granting of relief is justified. Consequently, this measure contains provisions for the inevitable cases of hardship. Under those provisions such cases will be dealt with sympathetically. The Commissioner for Taxation will be required to give a decision in cases of hardship within 30 days. Should he fail to do so or should his decision be unacceptable to the applicant for relief, the applicant may apply to one of the fourteen land valuation boards that operate throughout the Commonwealth. Everything will be done wisely arid expeditiously to grant wool-growers relief from any hardship that may be caused by the wool sales deduction. The Government does not wish to impose an oppressive measure on any section of the community, or to. treat it unjustly. I am sure that the sensible wool-growers, and the sensible people of Australia, will realize that the economic conditions of the wool industry are out of harmony with the national economy. It is in order to harmonize those conditions, and for no other reason, that the Government is asking the wool industry to contribute a part of its fortuitous income as a pre-payment of tax in the present difficult year; a year in which the Government will incur extraordinary and unforeseen expenditure; a year in which our defence programme must be brought forward as expeditiously as possible; a year in which, OUr defence commitments, in order that we may make our proper contribution as a member of the United Nations, will require the expenditure of an additional £79,000,000 compared with the expenditure on defence last year. Yet the Opposition would have us believe that the amount of £103,000,000 that the Government expects to collect by way of the wool sales deduction should not be used in connexion with that expenditure.

A great deal has been said in this debate about the present inflationary conditions. I emphasize that if the Government is to meet the estimated expenditure of £738,000,000 during this financial year, it must utilize £103,000,000 of the fortuitous income that is being derived by the wool-growers. Otherwise, that money must be left in the hands of the wool-growers, and the Government must borrow a similar amount from the Commonwealth Bank by way of treasury bills. Such a method of finance would accelerate the spiral of inflation. The Opposition asks the Government to permit the wool-growers to retain that amount of £103,000,000, and pay their income tax in the ordinary course as it becomes due, and, in the meantime, meet its indispensable commitments by borrowing £103,000,000 by way of treasury bills. That proposal would produce double inflation, because £103,000,000 would be obtained by treasury-bills, and £103,000,000 of purchasing power would be released in the community via the wool-growers' cheques. Yet the Opposition claims that the wool sales deduction proposal will not combat the present inflationary conditions ! Let us consider for a moment the nature of our expenditure during this financial year. A strategic stock pile is to be established, at a cost of £50,000,000, a big proportion of which will he expended upon imports. The Postal Department will incur sub stantial expenditure on equipment, the bulk of which was ordered some years ago from other countries. Will not that be an anti-inflationary, or deflationary measure ?

I have been criticized for including capital expenditure in my calculations. I have never been happy about making provision for capital expenditure out of revenue, but the present circumstances leave me with no alternative. The loan market, out of which capital works may be financed, is limited. If the Consolidated Revenue account is relieved of such capital expenditure, taxation must be reduced to a corresponding degree. But such a policy would be inflationary. The Opposition claims that the collections from the wool sales deduction should not be included in the revenue account for this financial year, but should be regarded as future revenue. Even if we grant that such an argument is logical, we can sensibly and successfully claim that £69,000,000 of capital expenditure, for which provision is made in the budget, is for the benefit and welfare of the nation in the future. The amount of £103,000,000 that the Government expects to obtain by way of the wool sales deduction is to be part and parcel of the means of financing it. Therefore, it does not matter how we examine the problem. The matter has been wisely planned, and the Government is measuring up to its responsibilities.

The Opposition has claimed that the operation of this bill should be limited to one year, but the very nature of the scheme precludes the adoption of such a temporary provision. As with income tax procedure, the Government will be required to introduce a bill to establish the rate of the wool sales deduction each financial year. That is to say, the rate will be fixed by the Parliament, and a safeguard is provided that the amount which may be deducted shall not exceed 20 per cent. A responsible government will have to determine whether this legislation shall be reenacted in future. I make the definite promise that this measure will not remain on the statute-book for one minute longer than the economic circumstances and conditions of the country warrant. This is a temporary provision, but its duration must be conditioned by the economic circumstances that a changing world is forcing upon us almost from day to day. The contention that the operation of this bill should be limited to a specified period is irresponsible humbug, but I emphasize that this measure will not be administered for one minute longer than the economic conditions of the country warrant.

talk.start.para: - Will the wool-growers be taxed again next year?

- They may be. Opposition members are displaying a newly found love for the wool-growers. Mary's affection for her little lamb was as nothing compared with the love that members of the Labour party pretend to have for the wool-growers. However, that solicitude will not deceive the wool-growers, or any one associated with the wool industry. The House is asked to believe that the small wool-grower will suffer considerable financial hardship when he is compelled to pay the wool sales deduction. Are not Opposition members aware that wool is selling for £150 a bale ? What was the position of the small woolgrower last year when wool was bringing £80 a bale? Was he financially embarrassed? I have never heard so much humbug as the speeches of Opposition members on this proposal. A woolgrower who considers that the wool sales deduction affects him harshly or oppressively may apply to the Commissioner of Taxation for relief, and his case will receive sympathetic and practical consideration.

speech.para: Much misleading criticism of the wool sales deduction has been published outside the Parliament. I direct attention to a full-page advertisement that appeared in the Canberra Times recently. It purports to give the financial position of a member of an organization known as the United Farmers. I challenge Mr. Chapman, who is responsible for that advertisement, to state the membership of the organization, and' to produce the taxpayer whose financial circumstances were cited. I should like to examine his income tax returns, not as the Commonwealth Treasurer. but as an accountant. I suggest that such an investigation would disclose that the allegations were based upon stupidity. The statement showed the income and the expenditure of a grower who produced 30 bales of wool, and it was misleading in two important respects. It showed that, during the current financial year, that grower would receive £3,000 for 30 bales of wool, or an average return of £100 a bale. Yet the average price .for 87,343 bales of greasy wool during the months of July and August, 1950, which were the " lightest " months this year, was £141 7s. On that basis, 30 bales of wool would realize £4,240, that is, £1,240 more than the income shown in the published statement. The other misleading item was in respect of working expenses, which were shown as £2,400, representing £80 for every bale of wool produced,. Would it cost £80 to produce a bale of wool? This fellow's income tax return is worth an examination, because if he is getting away with £2,400 as allowable expenses for the production of 30 bales of wool, he is dodging income tax.

I have prepared a statement showing the working results which might be expected by a grower with approximately 1,Q00 sheep, under normal conditions and under the wool sales deduction scheme. With the consent of honorable members,
I shall incorporate it in Hansard. It is as follows: -

I have now replied to the principal matters that have been raised in this debate. I have proved conclusively that the present economic circumstances require action to be taken by the Government to harmonize the economy of the wool industry with the general economy of Australia. I have pointed out that the wool sales deduction proposal is, in all the circumstances, the most equitable and sensible that can be evolved to meet that position. It is not confiscation, and it does not discriminate against the wool-growers. It is not a wool tax, but a prepayment provision to meet future tax assessments. The wool industry is not to be asked to pay one shilling more than it would normally pay in tax. All that it is asked to do is to pay tax earlier than is usual, and thereby assist the Government to solve the economic problems of the country. It will be found, in the final analysis, that this proposal is in the best interests of the wool industry itself.

talk.start.para: . - I take advantage of this opportunity to bring to the attention of the House and the Government what appears to have been a prearranged question that was asked yesterday by the honorable member for Corio (Mr. Opperman) and was answered by the Minister for Supply (Mr. Beale). That answer to that question cast a reflection on the honesty and integrity of Mr. J. J. Dedman, a former Minister of the Crown, a former member of this Parliament, and a present member of the Labour movement. The impression left by the question and the answer was that the question was what is popularly known as a "Dorothy Dix", which is a question, the terms of which have already been communicated to the Minister so that the Minister can prepare an answer to it. I consider that the prepared answer to this question was calculated to damage the personal reputation of Mr. Dedman. Indeed, it cast a grave reflection on his honesty and integrity by indicating that Mr. Dedman had used a Commonwealth car for his own private or political purposes. That statement is, according to my information, completely slanderous misrepresentation. I took the opportunity of getting in touch with Mr. Dedman, and I received a spontaneous telegram from the secretary of the Australian Council of Trades Unions, Mr. Broadby. Mr. Broadby said in that message -

quote.para: I strongly resent attacks made on Dedman yesterday by Beale. The representative of the central committee of the C.R.T.S. requested Dedman last January after consultation with Melbourne Trades Hall Council to cover Geelong area as accredited trade union representative in company with department's assessing officers. I informed Director Reestablishment Division of my wishes who raised no objection. In view of hundred per cent cooperation in administration of C.R.T.S. we feel that Beale's statement should be at oner challenged. We demand that we retain right to delegate supervision of trainees to representatives of our own choice.

speech.para: I personally took the opportunity of asking Mr. Dedman whether there was any truth at all in the suggestion that he had used a Commonwealth car for his own private or political purposes. Mr. Dedman informed me that he had never at any time used a Commonwealth car for his own private or political purposes except when he was a member of this Parliament, but that he had travelled in one as a representative of the Australian Council of Trades Unions. The assessing officer of the relevant department, presumably the Repatriation Department or the Department of Labour and National Service, received instructions from other officers in Geelong to the effect that Mr. Dedman could accompany him to that city in a Commonwealth car. Mr. Dedman did travel with a Commonwealth officer as a representative of the Australian Council of Trades Unions, and was approved by the department concerned as a representative of the Australian Council of Trades Unions. The government car was being used by an officer associated with the reconstruction training, scheme in the perf ormance of his routine duties. Here is Mr. Dedman's own statement on the incident -

quote.para: I have accompanied these assessors when they visited the Geelong area, and naturally travelled with them in a Commonwealth car. At no time did I travel on my own in a Commonwealth car, and politics were never mentioned while I was visiting the trainees.

speech.para: No member of this House, who is personally acquainted with Mr. Dedman, would question his honesty and integrity. The question asked in the House on this subject, and the answer that was given to it, represented an attempt to damage Mr. Dedman's reputation, politically and personally. Mr. Broadby spoke to the honorable member for Bendigo (Mr. Clarey) during the day, and pointed out that if the representative of the Australian Council of Trades Unions, who was cooperating with the Government in the reconstruction training scheme, was to be subjected to slander for political purposes, the government could not expect much co-operation in the future. If Mr. Dedman is to be denied the right to travel in a Commonwealth car, in the company of departmental officers, while he is engaged on work connected with the reconstruction training scheme, then other union officers must be denied that right also. It is clear that Mr. Dedman did not use the car for his own purposes, but travelled in it only when he was representing the Australian Council of Trades Unions on work associated with the reconstruction training scheme.

talk.start.para: . - I take this opportunity to comment on a decision announced earlier to-day regarding those Australians who have gone to Poland to attend a so-called peace congress. On the 31st August, the Australian Government announced the decision that henceforth passports issued by it to Australian citizens would exclude certain countries from travel unless prior permission had been obtained. Simultaneously, Australian representatives abroad were notified to write similar restrictions into any passports, previously issued, which might come under their notice. The countries excluded are all considered to be under Communist control. It was announced at the time that this decision would be reviewed at the end of twelve months, in the light of the then existing international situation.

speech.para: As I have said many times, this Government regards the right to travel freely as one of the most important privileges enjoyed by any citizen, and the decision imposing these restrictions was not taken lightly. It was a carefully considered decision, reached after consultation with security authorities here and elsewhere, and upon the recommendation of our own security service. It was made quite clear that if an applicant for a passport had a legitimate reason for visiting any of the excluded countries and he was not regarded as a security risk, the question of whether or not his passport should be endorsed accordingly would receive consideration on the merits of the case.

We Australians cannot regard ourselves as living in a normal period of peace, when Australian troops are fighting and dying in Korea, and when the democratic world is strengthening itself to resist the menace of aggressive Communist imperialism. It is against this background that the issue raised by Australians who have proceeded to Poland for the so-called peace congress, must be viewed. No one with a knowledge of recent history should entertain any illusions as to the nature and purpose of this congress. It fits with earlier and similarly spurious conferences into the pattern of a predetermined Communist programme. It is not merely a vehicle for Communist propaganda. There can be no doubt that it will, at the same time, provide a convenient opportunity for treacherous conspiracy and covert planning. It is designed to embarrass and weaken those democratic countries with which Australia's vital interests are linked.

At the time when most of the delegates applied for their passports, the restrictions to be written into the passport were known, as also were the reasons for this restriction. Now, without even going through the formality of seeking permission to travel to one of the excluded countries, and with the knowledge that their action was contrary to the policy of their own Government, a number of delegates have chosen to ignore the limitation and to defy their Government. No Go'vernment with a shred of responsibility could disregard this impudent refusal to observe the prescribed conditions.

The powers available to us in the circumstances are limited, but one power we do possess, and that is the authority to cancel the passport of any offender. Our passport is an official travel document that is issued under the authority of the Government of the Commonwealth and is signed by the Governor-General. It requests in the name of the King those whom it may concern " to allow the bearer to pass freely without let or hindrance, and to afford him every assistance and protection of which he may stand in need ". We feel under no obligation to continue this request and to maintain this privilege for those delegates who have proceeded to Poland and apparently imagine they can defy their Government with impunity. Indeed, we have a duty in the interest of national security generally to see that our policy shall be respected. I have accordingly instructed that the passport of any person travelling without prior permission to the congress at Poland is to be deemed to have been cancelled. My department has notified our representa tives abroad, and international transport authorities to this effect.

talk.start.para: .- I wish to associate myself with the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Chifley) regarding the answer given yesterday by the Minister for Supply (Mr. Beale) to a question asked by the honorable member for Corio (Mr. Opperman). I was in the chamber when the honorable member for Corio asked his question. In effect, he asked whether the Minister was aware that an ex-member of the Parliament had been using government cars for political purposes. Obviously, he implied that he had made inquiries into the matter and was satisfied that the gentleman he had in mind had used government cars for political purposes. The Minister, when replying, gave the impression that he had investigated the matter and had found that the implication contained in the honorable member's question was correct. The Minister also publicly expressed hiE disapproval of Mr. Dedman's alleged action in a manner that 'belittled that gentleman's reputation as an ex-member of the Parliament. In view of the facts that the Australian Council of Trades Unions has placed before me, I strongly protest against the question that the honorable member for Corio asked and also against the reply that the Minister gave to it.

speech.para: I shall give those facts to the House. At no time has Mr. Dedman been in a government car in the Geelong area, or in the Corio electorate, except in order to carry out duties that the trade union movement appointed him to carry out in accordance with the Commonwealth reconstruction training scheme. In order to succeed, that scheme requires the cooperation of both employers, and employees, and the Australian Council of Trades Unions throughout Australia has given it 100 per cent, support. In doing so, however, it has found it necessary to appoint persons to carry out certain functions that are prescribed under the act under which the scheme is being implemented. I indicate how strongly the Australian Council of Trades Unions feels on this matter by pointing out that a large number of trade unionists, without fee or reward, have given a great deal of their time solely in order to promote this worthy scheme. When I was president of the Australian Council of Trades Unions I spent days attending conferences at which details of the scheme were hammered out.

Under that scheme, Mr. Broadby, the secretary of the Australian Council of Trades Unions, was appointed to accompany assessors when they were engaged in assessing the progress that had been made by trainees. Obviously, the secretary of the Australian Council of Trades Unions is not able to devote the whole of his time to that important work. Consequently, with the concurrence of the Melbourne Trades Hall Council, Mr. Dedman was appointed as an associate regional officer to act on behalf of Mr. Broadby from time to time. In that capacity, Mr. Dedman is obliged to accompany assessors when they are assessing the degree of progress that has been made by trainees. The practice is that when the assessor goes to an establishment at which a trainee is employed to make an assessment of the trainee's progress, he is accompanied by a representative of the trade union movement in order, on behalf of the trade union movement as a whole, to ensure that the assessment shall be made correctly and that full opportunity shall be given to any trainee concerned to place his case clearly before the assessor. Mr. Dedman, who is an ex-member of the Parliament, and has had a great deal of experience in industrial matters, has been appointed to do that job and he has followed the practice of accompanying assessors in the circumstances that I have indicated.

talk.start.para: - But only in the electorate in which he stood as a candidate for the Parliament.

- If the Government intends to look at the matter from the stand-point that the honorable member who has interjected has implied, it will mean that rather than ensure that the Commonwealth reconstruction training scheme shall be properly administered, the Government will be more concerned about the political and industrial history of persons whom the trade union movement appoints to enable it to co-operate with it in this scheme. If that be so, the Australian Council of Trades Unions will naturally conclude that the Government no longer requires its co-operation. All that that body asks is that when it appoints a person to do a job of .the kind that I have indicated, the Government shall not spurn its co-operation because the person whom it appoints for that purpose is obliged to carry out his functions in an area that he previously represented in the Parliament. Apparently the Government does not regard such an individual as a fit and proper person to carry out those duties. The matter has arisen because Mr. Dedman has accompanied the assessor in a government car in an area in which he lives and which he represented in the Parliament. It is possible that when I am no longer a member of the Parliament, I shall be appointed to perform duties for the trade union movement in similar circumstances. If the Government takes that view, its attitude is more likely to lead to the breakdown rather than to the encouragement of the Commonwealth reconstruction training scheme. L sincerely hope that in view of the facts that I have presented, both the honorable member for Corio who asked the question and the Minister should, in fairness to the Australian Council of Trades Unions and to Mr. Dedman,, express regret for the part that they have played in this episode.

. - To-day, I received a circular issued by the Ministry of National Development which deals with major works that are being carried out under the authority of the Australian Government and the State governments. I refer to the following item that appears on page 10 of that document: -

quote.para: New South Wales. - Branxton-Muswellbrook rail duplication - It is anticipated that this scheme, estimated to cost over £2,000,000 will be completed within five years. The duplication will facilitate the handling of additional traffic anticipated as a result of increased coal output from existing mines and those in course of development in this area.

speech.para: The period of five years, which I presume has been estimated by the State Government as this is a State work, is grossly excessive because this undertaking is necessary and urgent. The production of the existing mines at Muswellbrook is reduced from time to time owing to the lack of rail facilities. In fact, new mines that are being opened up south of Muswellbrook are arranging to send coal 26 miles by road. This will add to the cost of that coal and, at the same time, will destroy the road, which is not built to carry heavy traffic. This area is capable of considerably increasing its present coal production. Until this line has been duplicated, that capacity cannot be fully utilized. There is a great waste of rolling-stock because of the delays that occur on the single line. That waste would be eliminated if the line were duplicated. Some of the work of duplicating the line has already been done. There are no major engineering projects involved. The only big bridge is the one across the Hunter River, which already provides for a double track. It is true that a short deviation of 6 miles has to be made between Glennie's Creek and Singleton, but that is not a major work. To show just how fantastic the estimate of five years is, I point out that in the ten years between 1875 and 1884, 1,215 miles of new railway line was built in New South "Wales. That is approximately 121 miles a year, and there were no bulldozers, compressors or mechanical drills in those days, yet, with all the equipment now available, it is estimated that five years will be required to complete the urgent job of duplicating 45 miles of line. I looked up the records of the building of the original line from Branxton to Muswellbrook. It was built between 1863 and 1869 - a period of six years. I do not know whether the work was continuous throughout that period, but the official railway guide of 1879 referred to the comparatively slow progress that was being made. Thus, nearly 100 years ago, the people of this country were ashamed of having taken six years to build that pioneering line.

talk.start.para: - How many men worked on it?

- I do not know, but if more men are needed to carry out the duplication, they should be employed. It is incredible that it will take five years to duplicate this bottleneck line which is so reducing coal production. I believe that the State Government is deliberately delaying the work because it does not want the open-cut coal-fields to be developed. It is a major scandal.

.I wish to say something about the question that was asked to-day by the honorable member for Corio (Mr. Opperman) about the alleged use by Mr. Dedman of a Commonwealth car. I remind honorable members that Mr. Dedman had a splendid record in World War I. .He attained the rank of captain in the British Army while he was very young. Subsequently, he came to this country, to which, in the intervening years, he has rendered splendid service. He was primarily responsible for the conception and the implementation of the post-war reconstruction plan, which is the finest of its kind in the world. Under that scheme, doctors, lawyers, architects, engineers and tradesmen of all kinds who were unable to undergo or complete their training because of the war, were given an opportunity to do so upon their return, and are now serving this country in their various vocations. Further, Mr. Dedman was largely the author and the planner of Labour's full employment scheme, and so has made a name for himself in the history of this Commonwealth. That, in itself, of course, would not entitle him to use a Commonwealth car without authority, or even to travel in one, but, at least it shows the wisdom of Mr. Broadby, who is the trade union regional officer, in requesting that Mr. Dedman should act as his deputy in the work of assessing the capacity of trainees. It is most unfair that anybody, for party political purposes, should endeavour to blacken the reputation, integrity and honesty of a man of Mr. Dedman's standing. The suggestion- is, of course, that Mr. Dedman used his visits to training centres to advance his own party political ends. I assure the honorable member for Corio that Mr. Dedman does not need to advance his claims by means such as that. He will re-enter this House because of the failure of the present Government to carry out its promises to reduce taxation, to put value back into the £1, and to free the people of Australia from their bondage.

. - I regret that it is necessary for me to speak at this late hour, and I shall be brief. I wish to amplify the remarks that have been made by the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) about the duplication of the Branxton to Muswellbrook railway line. I have before me a document prepared by the Minister for National Development (Mr. Casey) showing the developmental works that are to be carried out by the various States at an estimated total cost exceeding £500,000 each. When one studies this document, one is appalled at the complete failure of the Government of New South Wales to face up to the practical implications of a policy of decentralization. As the honorable member for Mackellar said, the duplication of the line from Branxton to Muswellbrook is to take five years. The estimated cost of the work is £2,000,000. Yet, the electrification of the line from Sydney to Lithgow, the estimated cost of which is £7,000,000 is scheduled for completion by 1954 ! The significance of those figures is this: The line from Branxton to Muswellbrook not only touches the coal-fields to which the honorable member for Mackellar has referred, but also is a part of the link between Maryvale and Sandy Hollow, better known as the Dubbo to Newcastle line. Already £2,300,000 has been expended on that line. Within the last few days the New South Wales Minister for Railways or his officers informed a deputation that it was impossible to get sufficient material and staff to complete that line. That is a howling disgrace to the State of New South Wales. The deputation asked that a small section of the line be completed to facilitate the tapping of the open-cut coal deposits at Wollar. Actually, that railway line should be completed in the interests of economy and of efficient working. I am able to state from personal knowledge, because I was a member of the Public Works Committee of the Parliament of New South Wales which reported upon the matter, that the grade of the line from Dubbo to Newcastle, which incor porates the Branxton to Muswellbrook duplication, is 1 in 50 each way. The route crosses the Dividing Range at the lowest point, and the grade can be made 1 in 70 without much additional expense. The grade of the railway line over the Blue Mountains is 1 in 30 both ways. For the purpose of centralization, the State Government is pursuing a policy of dragging goods up and down that terrific grade rather than building a line that would save rolling-stock and coal, open the coal deposits on both the Wollar and the Muswellbrook side, and foster decentralization.

speech.para: I note that, according to this document, it is proposed to provide eleven power stations in Queensland. Only one of them is not under construction. Eight power stations will be provided for New South Wales. Three of them are not under construction, but not one power station will be built north of Newcastle in that magnificent area, which contributed £125,000,000 - actually more than South Australia contributed - to the wealth of Australia last year. That area is " crying out " for development. I do not know whether the Commonwealth has power to influence such matters, but I hope that wiser counsels will prevail, or that a wiser Government will take office in New South Wales, so that its resources will be developed and the population of the State will be distributed more effectively than is possible under this mad-headed, wrong and entirely ill-balanced proposal in the national development scheme.

talk.start.para: . - I support the remarks of the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth), with which must necessarily be associated those of the honorable member for New England (Mr. Drummond). It is true that, if it will take five years to duplicate the BranxtonMuswellbrook railway line, some authority is insufficiently seised of the need for greater coal production in this country, and that must necessarily be the Government of New South Wales. I do not propose to impute motives, but I believe that, in view of the tragic shortage of coal and of the tremendous potential of the open-cut. coal deposits between .Singleton and Muswellbrook, action must be taken by the Commonwealth to bring home to the State Government the need to carry out that work with greater speed. [Quorum formed.] The tragic fact is. that, although 2;500 tons of coal could be produced daily from the Muswellbrook open cut coal deposit by the present staff with the existing equipment, not more than 2,000 tons is being shifted. In other words, 500 tons of coal is lost daily, due primarily to the lack of suitable rolling-stock. But if that railway line were duplicated, the quicker turn-round of coal trucks would remove the limitation that is now imposed by transport on the output of opencut coal at Muswellbrook. The duplication would provide a railway line without steep grades, on which lighter locomotives could pull heavier trains at higher speeds. In that way, the output of coal from the opencut mine would be increased tremendously, and a great contribution would be made thereby to Australia's coal production. Therefore, I support the remarks of the honorable member for Mackellar, and trust that the Commonwealth will bring all possible pressure to bear on the Government of New South Wales to make the manpower and materials available for the purpose of completing the duplication of the BranxtonMuBwellbrook railway line at a much earlier date than is now contemplated.
